api-reference/agent.title: Agent API
api-reference/agent.description: The Agent class is the core component of Tyler, responsible for managing conversations and executing tasks. It uses Pydantic for data validation and Weave for monitoring and tracing.

api-reference/attachment.title: Attachment API
api-reference/attachment.description: The Attachment class represents files attached to messages in Tyler. It handles file content storage, processing, and retrieval, supporting both direct content storage and external file storage backends.

api-reference/index.title: API Reference
api-reference/index.description: This section provides detailed documentation for Tyler's core components and APIs. Each page covers a specific component's interface, methods, and usage patterns.

api-reference/message.title: Message API
api-reference/message.description: The Message class represents individual interactions within a thread. It handles text content, attachments, and metadata for each message in a conversation.

api-reference/thread.title: Thread API
api-reference/thread.description: The Thread class manages conversations and maintains context between messages. It's responsible for organizing messages, handling system prompts, and storing conversation metadata.

api-reference/thread-store.title: ThreadStore API
api-reference/thread-store.description: The ThreadStore class provides persistent storage for threads using SQLAlchemy, supporting both PostgreSQL and SQLite backends. It handles thread storage, retrieval, and management with automatic attachment handling.

api-reference/tools.title: Tools
api-reference/tools.description: The Tools API in Tyler provides a way to define and use custom tools that your agent can interact with.

built-in-tools.title: Built-in tools
built-in-tools.description: Tyler comes with a set of built-in tools that provide common functionality for AI agents. These tools are ready to use out of the box and can be enabled or disabled as needed.

category/api-reference.title: API Reference
category/api-reference.description: This section provides detailed documentation for Tyler's core APIs. Here you'll find comprehensive information about the main classes and interfaces that make up the framework.

category/examples.title: Examples
category/examples.description: This section contains various examples of how to use Tyler in different scenarios. Each example demonstrates specific features and use cases of the framework.

chat-with-tyler.title: Chat with Tyler
chat-with-tyler.description: Tyler provides two interactive interfaces for chatting with your agent:

configuration.title: Configuration guide
configuration.description: Tyler offers extensive configuration options to customize its behavior for your specific needs. This guide covers all available configuration options and their usage.

core-concepts.title: Core concepts
core-concepts.description: This guide explains the core concepts and components that make up Tyler's architecture.

examples/database-storage.title: Database Storage
examples/database-storage.description: This example demonstrates how to use persistent database storage with Tyler, including PostgreSQL integration and metrics tracking.

examples/file-storage.title: File Storage Example
examples/file-storage.description: This example demonstrates how to use Tyler's file storage capabilities to save and retrieve files.

examples/full-configuration.title: Full Configuration
examples/full-configuration.description: This example demonstrates how to use all available configuration options in Tyler, including custom tools, persistent storage, and monitoring.

examples/index.title: Examples
examples/index.description: This section contains examples demonstrating various features and use cases of Tyler.

examples/interrupt-tools.title: Interrupt Tools
examples/interrupt-tools.description: This example demonstrates how to create and use interrupt tools in Tyler. Interrupt tools can stop the normal conversation flow to handle special situations like content moderation or user confirmation.

examples/message-attachments.title: Message Attachments
examples/message-attachments.description: This example demonstrates how to work with file attachments in Tyler messages, including adding files, automatic processing, and storage management.

examples/streaming.title: Streaming Responses
examples/streaming.description: Tyler supports streaming responses from the agent, allowing you to build highly interactive applications that show responses in real-time. This example demonstrates how to use streaming with both basic responses and tool execution.

examples/tools-streaming.title: Tools with Streaming
examples/tools-streaming.description: This example demonstrates how to combine tool execution with streaming responses, allowing you to build interactive applications that can perform actions while providing real-time feedback.

examples/using-tools.title: Using Tools
examples/using-tools.description: This example demonstrates how to use both built-in and custom tools with Tyler. It shows how to create a custom tool for posting to Slack and combine it with the built-in web tools.

how-it-works.title: How Tyler works
how-it-works.description: Tyler's architecture is designed to make building AI agents simple while providing all the components needed for production use. Let's dive into how Tyler processes requests and manages conversations.

installation.title: Installation Guide
installation.description: This guide will walk you through the process of installing Tyler and setting up your development environment on macOS.

intro.title: Meet Tyler
intro.description: Tyler makes it easy to start building effective AI agents in just a few lines of code. Tyler provides all the essential components needed to build production-ready AI agents that can understand context, manage conversations, and effectively use tools.

quick-start.title: Quick start
quick-start.description: This guide will help you install Tyler and create your first AI agent.

tools/command-line.title: Command Line Tools
tools/command-line.description: The command line module provides safe access to system commands. It includes a carefully curated set of whitelisted commands that can be executed within the workspace.

tools/custom-tools.title: Building Custom Tools
tools/custom-tools.description: Tyler's functionality can be extended by creating custom tools. This guide explains how to build, test, and integrate your own tools.

tools/image.title: Image Tools
tools/image.description: The image module provides tools for generating and manipulating images using DALL-E 3. These tools allow you to create high-quality images from text descriptions.

tools/notion.title: Notion Tools
tools/notion.description: The Notion module provides tools for interacting with Notion workspaces. These tools allow you to search, read, and manage Notion pages and databases.

tools/overview.title: Tools Overview
tools/overview.description: Tyler comes with several built-in tool modules that provide various capabilities out of the box. Each module can be enabled by including its name in the agent's tools configuration.

tools/slack.title: Slack Tools
tools/slack.description: The Slack module provides tools for interacting with Slack workspaces. These tools allow you to send messages, create channels, and manage users within your Slack workspace.

tools/web.title: Web Tools
tools/web.description: The web module provides tools for interacting with web content. These tools allow you to fetch and process web pages in various formats.

troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting
troubleshooting.description: Common issues and their solutions when working with Tyler.
